segments.en: Numbered Discourses 8
1. Love
8. Uttara on Failure

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā uttaro mahisavatthusmiṃ viharati saṅkheyyake pabbate vaṭajālikāyaṃ.
segments.en: At one time Venerable Uttara was staying on the Saṅkheyyaka Mountain in the Mahisa region near Dhavajālikā.

segments.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā uttaro bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: There Uttara addressed the mendicants:

segments.pli: “sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attavipattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.
segments.en: “Mendicants, it’s good for a mendicant to check their own failings from time to time.

segments.pli: Sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ paravipattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.
segments.en: It’s good for a mendicant to check the failings of others from time to time.

segments.pli: Sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attasampattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.
segments.en: It’s good for a mendicant to check their own successes from time to time.

segments.pli: Sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ parasampattiṃ paccavekkhitā hotī”ti.
segments.en: It’s good for a mendicant to check the successes of others from time to time.”

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vessavaṇo mahārājā uttarāya disāya dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ gacchati kenacideva karaṇīyena.
segments.en: Now at that time the great king Vessavaṇa was on his way from the north to the south on some business.

segments.pli: Assosi kho vessavaṇo mahārājā āyasmato uttarassa mahisavatthusmiṃ saṅkheyyake pabbate vaṭajālikāyaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evaṃ dhammaṃ desentassa:
segments.en: He heard Venerable Uttara teaching this to the mendicants on Saṅkheyyaka Mountain.

segments.pli: “sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attavipattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.
Sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ paravipattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.
Sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attasampattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.
Sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ parasampattiṃ paccavekkhitā hotī”ti.

Atha kho vessavaṇo mahārājā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ mahisavatthusmiṃ saṅkheyyake pabbate vaṭajālikāyaṃ antarahito devesu tāvatiṃsesu pāturahosi.
segments.en: Then Vessavaṇa vanished from Saṅkheyyaka Mountain and appeared among the gods of the Thirty Three, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm.

segments.pli: Atha kho vessavaṇo mahārājā yena sakko devānamindo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then he went up to Sakka, lord of gods, and said to him:
“Please sir, you should know this.

segments.pli: Eso āyasmā uttaro mahisavatthusmiṃ saṅkheyyake pabbate vaṭajālikāyaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evaṃ dhammaṃ deseti:
segments.en: Venerable Uttara is teaching the mendicants on Saṅkheyyaka Mountain in this way:

segments.pli: ‘sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attavipattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.
segments.en: ‘It’s good for a mendicant from time to time to check their own failings. …

segments.pli: Sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ paravipattiṃ … pe …
segments.en: the failings of others …
their own successes …
the successes of others.’

segments.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ devesu tāvatiṃsesu antarahito mahisavatthusmiṃ saṅkheyyake pabbate vaṭajālikāyaṃ āyasmato uttarassa sammukhe pāturahosi.
segments.en: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, Sakka vanished from the gods of the Thirty Three and reappeared on Saṅkheyyaka Mountain in front of Venerable Uttara.

segments.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo yenāyasmā uttaro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ uttaraṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho sakko devānamindo āyasmantaṃ uttaraṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Sakka went up to Venerable Uttara, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:

segments.pli: “Saccaṃ kira, bhante, āyasmā uttaro bhikkhūnaṃ evaṃ dhammaṃ desesi:
segments.en: “Is it really true, sir, that you teach the mendicants in this way:

segments.pli: ‘sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attavipattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti,
segments.en: ‘It’s good for a mendicant from time to time to check their own failings …

segments.pli: sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ paravipattiṃ … pe …
segments.en: the failings of others …
their own successes …
the successes of others’?”
“Indeed, lord of gods.”

segments.pli: “Kiṃ panidaṃ, bhante, āyasmato uttarassa sakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ, udāhu tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassā”ti?
segments.en: “Sir, did this teaching come to you from your own inspiration, or was it spoken by the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
“Well then, lord of gods, I shall give you a simile.

segments.pli: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
segments.en: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, devānaminda, gāmassa vā nigamassa vā avidūre mahādhaññarāsi.
segments.en: Suppose there was a large heap of grain not far from a town or village.
And a large crowd were to take away grain
with carrying poles, baskets, hip sacks, or their cupped hands.

segments.pli: Yo nu kho, devānaminda, taṃ mahājanakāyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ puccheyya:
segments.en: If someone were to go to that crowd and ask them

segments.pli: ‘kuto imaṃ dhaññaṃ āharathā’ti, kathaṃ byākaramāno nu kho, devānaminda, so mahājanakāyo sammā byākaramāno byākareyyā”ti?
segments.en: where they got the grain from, how should that crowd rightly reply?”

segments.pli: “‘Amumhā mahādhaññarāsimhā āharāmā’ti kho, bhante, so mahājanakāyo sammā byākaramāno byākareyyā”ti.
segments.en: “Sir, they should reply that they took it from the large heap of grain.”

segments.pli: “Evamevaṃ kho, devānaminda, yaṃ kiñci subhāsitaṃ sabbaṃ taṃ tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
segments.en: “In the same way, lord of gods, whatever is well spoken is spoken by the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

segments.pli: Tato upādāyupādāya mayaṃ caññe ca bhaṇāmā”ti.
segments.en: Both myself and others rely completely on that when we speak.”
“It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing!
How well this was said by Venerable Uttara!

segments.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñci subhāsitaṃ sabbaṃ taṃ tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
segments.en: ‘Whatever is well spoken is spoken by the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
Both myself and others rely completely on that when we speak.’

segments.pli: Ekamidaṃ, bhante uttara, samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate acirapakkante devadatte.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain, not long after Devadatta had left.

segments.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā devadattaṃ ārabbha bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: There the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about Devadatta:

segments.pli: ‘Sādhu, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attavipattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.
segments.en: ‘Mendicants, it’s good for a mendicant from time to time to check their own failings …

segments.pli: Sādhu, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ paravipattiṃ … pe …
segments.en: the failings of others …
their own successes …
the successes of others.

segments.pli: Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, asaddhammehi abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto devadatto āpāyiko nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho.
segments.en: Overcome and overwhelmed by eight things that oppose the true teaching, Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.
What eight?

segments.pli: Lābhena hi, bhikkhave, abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto devadatto āpāyiko nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho;
segments.en: Overcome and overwhelmed by gain …
loss …
fame …
disgrace …
honor …
dishonor …
wicked desires …

segments.pli: pāpamittatāya, bhikkhave, abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto devadatto āpāyiko nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho.
segments.en: bad friendship, Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.

segments.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi asaddhammehi abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto devadatto āpāyiko nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho.
segments.en: Overcome and overwhelmed by these eight things that oppose the true teaching, Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.

segments.pli: Sādhu, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṃ lābhaṃ abhibhuyya abhibhuyya vihareyya;
segments.en: It’s good for a mendicant, whenever they encounter it, to overcome gain …
loss …
fame …
disgrace …
honor …
dishonor …
wicked desires …
bad friendship.

segments.pli: Kiñca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu atthavasaṃ paṭicca uppannaṃ lābhaṃ abhibhuyya abhibhuyya vihareyya;
segments.en: What advantage does a mendicant gain by overcoming these eight things?

segments.pli: Yaṃ hissa, bhikkhave, uppannaṃ lābhaṃ anabhibhuyya viharato uppajjeyyuṃ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, uppannaṃ lābhaṃ abhibhuyya viharato evaṃsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
segments.en: The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without overcoming these eight things do not arise when they have overcome them.

segments.pli: Yaṃ hissa, bhikkhave, uppannaṃ alābhaṃ … pe …
uppannaṃ pāpamittataṃ anabhibhuyya viharato uppajjeyyuṃ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, uppannaṃ pāpamittataṃ abhibhuyya viharato evaṃsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
Idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu atthavasaṃ paṭicca uppannaṃ lābhaṃ abhibhuyya abhibhuyya vihareyya;
segments.en: This is the advantage that a mendicant gains by overcoming these eight things.
So you should train like this:
“Whenever we encounter it, we will overcome gain …
loss …
fame …
disgrace …
honor …
dishonor …
wicked desires …
bad friendship.”
That’s how you should train.’

segments.pli: Ettāvatā, bhante uttara, manussesu catasso parisā—
segments.en: Sir, Uttara, this exposition of the teaching is not established anywhere in the four assemblies—
monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.

segments.pli: Uggaṇhatu, bhante, āyasmā uttaro imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ.
segments.en: Sir, learn this exposition of the teaching!

segments.pli: Pariyāpuṇātu, bhante, āyasmā uttaro imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ.
segments.en: Memorize this exposition of the teaching!

segments.pli: Dhāretu, bhante, āyasmā uttaro imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ.
segments.en: Remember this exposition of the teaching!
Sir, this exposition of the teaching is beneficial and relates to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”

suttaplex.blurb: In a discourse evidently set some time after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Uttara, staying in a distant land, teaches that a mendicant should review their own failings and those of others. Questioned by Sakka, the Lord of Gods, Uttara affirms that he learned this from the Buddha.
